text: <@U061HDV96>: there is a huge counter argument for that though
Playing devils advocate
if there was a way to get data *only for that specific phone* _without creating a skeleton key risking everyone else_, that potentially would be a good compromise
as <@U0546QERR> quoted, the big issue apple had was that creating this software solution basically would give the authorities a key to every iphone rather than just that particular device
<@U04U5KS3Z>: but in that case, there would be nothing stopping them from asking that more and more and more
to go through the process of getting a warrant then physically obtaining your device to then have to generate a new crack for it?
which would render the phone useless for use after so it’s not effective for long term surveillance
but if you’re already busted for something, they could easily have your device

if the warrant of reasonable suspicion, issued by an independent judge allows for it, and the authorities can only access your device alone without it compromising anyone else (e.g. no back doors, 3rd party key holders or skeleton keys). That seems reasonable to me - but maybe there’s a flaw in my thinking.
<@U04U5KS3Z> that fundamentally violates forensics rules. You can't destroy evidence otherwise how can we validate it?
Like do you really trust someone to hand over something that decides the fate of another and there is no way to validate what they find
maybe useless is the wrong word but once it's been accessed, it should be apparent that it has been accessed unconventionally - kind of like a seal that gets broken
kind of like a canary
<https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2016/02/sneaky-change-tpp-drastically-extends-criminal-penalties>

attachments.title: Sneaky Change to the TPP Drastically Extends Criminal Penalties
attachments.text: When the text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) was first released in November last year, it included provisions dictating the kinds of penalties that should be available in cases of copyright infringement. Amongst those provisions, the following footnote allowed countries some flexibility in applying criminal procedures and penalties to cases of willful copyright infringement on a commercial scale:
attachments.fallback: Electronic Frontier Foundation: Sneaky Change to the TPP Drastically Extends Criminal Penalties

text: <@U08GFT5V5> Scary. Thoughts on what we can do about this?
How did tech companies respond to Apple’s letter?
<http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/technology/tech-reactions-on-apple-highlight-issues-with-government-requests.html?ref=technology>
<@U0DMFJC0H>: No idea. EFF since to email our representatives
to stop congress from voting on this
<https://act.eff.org/action/tell-congress-to-vote-no-on-the-tpp>

attachments.title: Tell your lawmakers to protect digital rights and vote no on TPP.
attachments.text: The final text of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement has been released after more than five years of secret negotiations—and it's worse than we thought.
attachments.fallback: Tell your lawmakers to protect digital rights and vote no on TPP.
